page.title: 13PRENTON HALL
page.content: { Prenton Hall}appears in the Domesday Book as{Prestune,}meaning "dwelling of a priest". The existing building dates from the 16th century. The present owners, who are interested in its history, are helping local historians to uncover its past. It stands on the corner of the Roman Road, an old pack horse trail which may have been built by the Romans. In 1961 a visitor at the Hall saw the{ghost of a monk}watching over her in the lounge. There is{an old rhyme: "When gorse is in blossom and holly is green, the{Prenton Hall buggon}will then be seen". The Hall is split into two, one half is being made into flats. It used to be surrounded by 624 acres of land which have since been sold. The back of the Hall is now the front because of the modern houses on 3 sides of it.
